Never Installed: There is no policy package for this unit.
Either policies and objects have not been imported yet or no policy package has been assigned for this unit.

By elimination:

A. Out-of-Sync
B. Unknown
C. Modified
D. Never Installed

choices.C: The policy configuration has been changed on FortiManager and changes have not yet been installed on the managed device.
choices.A: The policy configuration has been changed on a managed device and changes have not yet been imported into FortiManager.
choices.D: The policy package was never imported after a device was registered on FortiManager.
choices.B: FortiManager is unable to determine the policy package status.

questions.question_text: What does a policy package status of Never Installed indicate?

choices.A: During discovery, the FortiManager NATed IP address is not set by default on FortiGate.
choices.B: If the FGFM tunnel is torn down, FortiManager will try to re-establish the FGFM tunnel.
choices.C: FortiGate is discovered by FortiManager through the FortiGate NATed IP address.
choices.D: FortiGate can announce itself to FortiManager only if the FortiManager non-NATed IP address is configured on FortiGate under central management.

discussion.content: AC is the correct answer

A and C...
page 279

AC: 

B is wrong: FortiManager doesn't automatically attempt to reestablish the FGFM tunnel if it is torn down.

Selected Answer: BC
Look at the study guide on page 277 and 279, it clearly states that when the FMG is behind a NATed IP, then it is ONLY the FMG that can discover a new device, and also is the only one that can re-establish the FGFM tunnel after it is torn down. Literally stated on the first paragraph of page 277. Page 279 where both are NATed, affirms that the scenario plays out exactly the same as when only the FMG was NATed. 
What I don't like about the question, is that A is also true, but only by deductive reasoning. So B and C are the better choices as they are clearly stated in the study guide as such.

Selected Answer: AC
AC is the correct answer ortiManager does not attempt to reestablish the FGFM tunnel to the FortiGate

comments.content: D says "non-NATed", Fortigate wont be able to reach that address

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Tricky one. It seems three answers are valid:

A. Correct. It can be configured on the FortiGate, but it is not by default.
B. Wrong. FortiManager does not attempt to reestablish the FGFM tunnel to the FortiGate NATed IP address.
C. Correct.
D. Correct.

choices.D: After 15 minutes, FortiGate will unset all CLI commands that were part of the installation that caused the tunnel to go down.
choices.A: FortiGate will reject the CLI commands that will cause the tunnel to go down.
choices.C: FortiManager will not push the CLI commands as part of the installation that will cause the tunnel to go down.
choices.B: FortiManager will revert and install a previous configuration revision on the managed FortiGate.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
FortiGate applies the unset command after 15 minutes
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
FortiManager 7.2
Diagnostics and Troubleshooting
p.281 If the connection fails to reestablish, FortiGate applies the unset command after 15 minutes (not configurable and not based on sock timeout values). If the connection remains down, and rollback-allow-reboot is enabled on FortiManager, FortiGate reboots to recover the previous configuration from its configuration file.

Selected Answer: D
A. Wrong. FortiGate applies the unset command after 15 minutes if the connection fails to reestablish.
B. Wrong. If the connection fails, FortiManager tries to recover the FGFM tunnel by unsetting the command that caused the tunnel to go down.
C. Wrong. If the connection fails, FortiManager tries to recover the FGFM tunnel by unsetting the command that caused the tunnel to go down.
D. Correct.

questions.question_text: When an installation is performed from FortiManager, what is the recovery logic used between FortiManager and FortiGate for an FGFM tunnel?

Lab Guide (p.21)
"Before you add FortiAnalyzer to FortiManager, you must enable the FortiManager Administrative Access checkbox on the FortiAnalyzer management interface."

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortianalyzer/7.2.0/administration-guide/578841/configuring-network-interfaces

Selected Answer: D
Tricky question as Probe Failed: Network can mean several things. But I'd go with option D. The 'fgfm-access’ on connecting interface must be enabled.

choices.A: The administrator must use the correct user name and password of the FortiAnalyzer device.
choices.D: The administrator must select the FortiManager administrative access checkbox on the FortiAnalyzer management interface.
choices.B: The administrator must turn off the Use Legacy Device login and add the FortiAnalyzer device to the same network as FortiManager.
choices.C: The administrator must use the Add Model Device section and discover the FortiAnalyzer device.
